batchr 0.0.0.900

Batch File Processing

batch_process.Rd

Performs batch processing of files in a directory using the batch_config(), batch_start() and batch_cleanup() functions.

batch_process(FUN, path = ".", pattern = ".*", recursive = FALSE,
  parallel = FALSE, logger = NULL, ...)

Arguments

FUN

A function to process each of the files.
path

A string of the path to the directory with the files.
pattern

A string of a regular expression. Only non-hidden file names which match the regular expression will be batch processed.
recursive

A flag specifying whether to recurse into sub directories.
parallel

A flag specifying whether to process the files in parallel (not yet used).
logger

A logger object that is passed to the file processing function to allow the user to log their own messages.
...

Additional arguments passed to FUN.

Value

A flag specifying whether all files were processed successfully.

Details

As well as the directory and a regular expression to identify files the user must provide the function that will be used to process each file. Processing is started (and can be manually restarted) using batch_start() which locks the configuration file with lock to prevent concurrent calls. The files that have not yet been processed can be got using batch_remaining_files().

The configuration details are saved in the '.batchr.rds file' which can be read using batch_read_config(). Configuration is only possible if the directory does not already contain a configuration file. If recursive = TRUE then the subdirectories must also not contain configuration files. Existing configuration files can be listed using batch_config_files().

The pattern must match at least one non-hidden file in the directory (or if recursive = TRUE in the directory or subdirectories). Hidden files are excluded to prevent accidental modification of system files.

The FUN function's first argument should be a string of the path to a single file. The function should return TRUE if processing was successful or FALSE if processing was unsuccessful. If the function returns FALSE the failure is automatically logged as an INFO message in the '.batchr.log' file.

Processing is also considered to have failed if the function throws an error. In this case the error is caught, the failure is logged as an ERROR message and batch processing resumes at the next file. If, however, the function returns an object other than a flag then a FATAL message is logged and processing ceases immediately with batchr throwing an error.

All failures are logged in the '.batchr.log' file with the level (WARN, ERROR, FATAL), system time in UTC and file name using a logger object. This information parsed as a tibble with level, time and file columns using batch_read_log().

The user can log custom messages by providing a logger object which is passed to the FUN function. In this case the FUN function must accept an argument called logger.

See also

batch_config(), batch_start() and batch_cleanup()
